H0.text: By checking the amount of water in the soil is the best way to predict which kind of pea will grow from a seed that is planted.

H1.text: By checking how often the pea plant receives sunlight, a student can best predict which kind of pea will grow from a seed that is planted.

H2.text: By checking how much space the plant will have to grow, a student can best predict which kind of pea will grow from a seed, because some pea plants always produce smooth‑skinned peas while others always produce wrinkled‑skinned peas.

H3.text: By checking the type of peas growing on the parent plants, a student can best predict which kind of pea will grow from a seed that is planted.

A4.text: The wrinkled phenotype of peas is caused by an insertion in the PsSBE1 gene. The yellow phenotype is caused by an insertion or mutation in the PsSGR gene.

A5.text: The white phenotype of the flower color (wild-type: purple) is caused by a deletion in the PsbHLH gene. The dwarf phenotype is caused by the PsGA3ox1 gene.

A6.text: The F1 offspring of Mendel's pea crosses always looked like one of the two parental varieties.

A7.text: He had the foresight to follow several successive generations (P, F1, F2, F3) of pea plants and record their variations.
